tit.cmt: 七口の関→Nanakuchi-no-seki(七口の関）[定訳不明]は、Nanakuchi No Seki (Seven Entrance Checkpoints)にしました。

sen.j: 七口の関（ななくちのせき）とは、中世に地方より京都に入る7つの街道（京都七口（きょうとななくち））に設置された関所のこと。
sen.e: "Nanakuchi no seki" refers to the checkpoints which were set on the seven roads leading to Kyoto from outlaying regions (Kyoto nanakuchi, Kyoto's seven entrances) in the medieval times.
sen.cmt: 京都七口→Kyoto-nanakuchi (seven roads)(京都七口）[定訳不明]は、Kyoto nanakuchi (Kyoto's seven entrances)にしました。

sen.j: 京都七口は元来、京都と七道を結ぶ街道の入口として設置されたと考えられ、大原口（小原口・八瀬口→北陸道）・鞍馬口（出雲路口）・粟田口（東三条口→東海道）・伏見口（宇治口・木幡口→南海道）・鳥羽口（→西海道）・丹波口（西七条口・七条口→山陰道）・長坂口（→(丹波道)）の7つと言われているが、これは関所が廃止された江戸時代以後の説で史実に即しているのか疑問を持たれている。
sen.e: It is considered that Kyoto nanakuchi were originally set as the entrances of the roads connecting Kyoto and seven circuits, which are said to be the Oohara entrance (the Ohara Entrance, the Yase entrance: the Hokuriku road), the Kurama entrance (the Izumo road entrance), the Awata entrance (the Higashi-sanjo entrance: the Tokai road), the Fushimi entrance (the Uji entrance, the Kohata entrance: the Nankai road), the Toba entrance (the Saikai road), the Tanba entrance (the Nishi-shichijo entrance, the Shichijo entrance: the Sanin road) and the Nagasaka entrance (the Tanba road), but this is the theory after the Edo Period when the checkpoints had been abolished, so there are doubts about whether this is a historical fact.
sen.cmt: 対訳欄の大原と小原がいずれもOharaになっていたので、それぞれOoharaとOharaにしました。西海道→the Sekai roadは、the Saikai roadに修正。
sen.e: It is thought that Kyoto nanakuchi were originally set as entrances to the roads connecting Kyoto and seven circuits, and are said to be the Oohara entrance (the Ohara Entrance, the Yase entrance: the Hokuriku road), the Kurama entrance (the Izumo road entrance), the Awata entrance (the Higashi-sanjo entrance: the Tokai road), the Fushimi entrance (the Uji entrance, the Kohata entrance: the Nankai road), the Toba entrance (the Saikai road), the Tanba entrance (the Nishi-shichijo entrance, the Shichijo entrance: the Sanin road) and the Nagasaka entrance (the Tanba road). However, this theory came about after the Edo Period and when such checkpoints had been abolished, so there are doubts surrounding whether these are historical facts.

sen.j: また、上記の関以外にも北白川口（今路道下→東山道）、東寺口（→山陽道）、法性寺口（→南海道）、西三条道（→(嵯峨道)）を七口の1つとして挙げている文書・史料も存在する。
sen.e: Other than those checkpoints above, some documents and historical materials name the Kita-shirakawa entrance (the Imamichi michishita: the Higashiyama road), the Higashi-dera entrance (the Sanyo road), the Hossho-ji entrance (the Nankai road) and the Nishi-sanjo road (the Saga road) as one of the Nanakuchi.

sen.j: そこで中世の七口の関について比定する研究も行われたが、実態として7つ以上の関所が存在したのは確実で、かつ現存記録でさえ七口に該当する場所がまちまちである以上、7つを特定することには意義はないとする見解もある。
sen.e: Therefore, studies to extrapolate the Nanakuchi no seki in the medieval times was conducted, but it is certain that more than seven checkpoints existed as reality, and even existing records have different points corresponding to the Nanakuchi, so there is also an opinion that it makes no sense to identify seven of them.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代以後、朝廷財政の衰微と荘園の拡大、交通の発達によって、内裏や寺社の修繕のために一定の通行料を取る関所が設置されるようになった。
sen.e: After the Kamakura Period, due to the decline of the Imperial Court's finance, expansion of private estates and progress in transportation, checkpoints were set up to take certain tolls for repair of the Imperial Palace, temples and shrines.

sen.j: 特に南北朝時代_(日本)によって財政難に拍車がかかると、朝廷が収入を確保するために各官庁に命じて内裏率分関（だいりりつぶんぜき・内裏率分所（だいりりつぶんしょ））を設置した。
sen.e: Especially in the Nanbokucho Period (Period of Northern and Southern Courts), when the financial difficulties were accelerated, the Imperial Court commanded each government office to set up Dairi-ritsubunseki (Imperial pro rata checkpoints, also called Dairi-ritsubunsho) in order to ensure their income.
sen.cmt: 南北朝時代→the Period of Northern and Southern Dynastiesは、the Nanbokucho Period (Period of Northern and Southern Courts)に訂正。（日本）は訳出せず。内裏率分関→Dairi-ritsubunseki(内裏率分関）[定訳不明]は、Dairi-ritsubunseki (Imperial pro rata checkpoints)にしました。

sen.j: 関所の代官は年貢・公事の納入以外で京都に入る商品や往来する人馬から率分に応じた商品あるいは一定の金額を通行税（関銭）として徴収した。
sen.e: A local magistrate of a checkpoint collected pro rata goods or certain amount of money as a passenger tax (sekisen, checkpoint charge) from the goods coming to Kyoto, and people and cargoes passing up and down, except the delivery for land taxes and political operations and ceremonies of the Imperial Court.
sen.cmt: 率分→ritsubun (the tax system where two-tenth of the tax delivered from the provinces to the Ministry of Finance at Heian-kyo were supplied to the tax storage called "ritsubun-do")（率分）[定訳不明]は、ritsubun (pro rata)にしました。関銭→sekisen(関銭）[定訳不明]は、sekisen (checkpoint charge)にしました。

sen.j: 高い通行料に苦慮した京都や山城国など周辺部の民衆は度々一揆を引き起こして関所の廃止を要求して、実力で関所を破壊することもあった。
sen.e: People in Kyoto and its neighboring regions including Yamashiro Province, who suffered through the high toll, often caused a rising to demand the abolishment of the checkpoints, and sometimes demolished the checkpoints by force.

sen.e: On the other hand, the Imperial Court and nobles repeated political maneuvering to have the Muromachi shogunate reject the people's demands.

sen.j: そればかりか、長禄3年（1459年）に伊勢神宮再建を名目に幕府自らが関を設置され、続いて文明_(日本)10年（1478年）には内裏再建を名目に再度関を設置した。
sen.e: Furthermore, the Shogunate itself set up a checkpoint in 1459 in the name of reconstruction of Ise Jingu Shrine, and then in 1478, set up a checkpoints again in the name of reconstruction of the Imperial Palace, and this setup turned out to be the income of Tomiko HINO, the lawful wife of Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdued the eastern barbarians") Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, so people vented their frustrations, which caused the uprising in Yamashiro Province lasting from that year for two years.
